Governments might also explore the development and implementation of central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) as an alternative to cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin. CBDCs would be issued and controlled by central banks, allowing governments to maintain control over monetary policy while potentially benefiting from the technological advantages of digital currencies.

In summary, while it is possible that people may increasingly turn to Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies in an unstable macroeconomic environment, the response from governments will depend on a range of factors, including the specific economic conditions, the legal and regulatory frameworks in place, and the perceived benefits and risks associated with cryptocurrencies. Governments may adopt a range of strategies, from embracing and regulating cryptocurrencies to implementing more restrictive measures in an attempt to maintain control over the financial system. However, the decentralized and digital nature of cryptocurrencies makes outright confiscation or bans significantly more challenging than historical gold confiscation.
